vision_json.prompt_sent:
Extract ONLY publication metadata from these academic paper pages.

CRITICAL: This data will be sent to 11 external APIs, so format accuracy is essential.

FIELD REQUIREMENTS WITH EXACT FORMATS:

1. **Title**: Clean title for API queries (HIGHEST PRIORITY)
   - Remove line breaks, extra spaces, formatting
   - No HTML tags or special characters  
   - Example: "Effects of Machine Learning on Healthcare Outcomes"

2. **Authors**: API-compatible author list (HIGHEST PRIORITY)
   - Each author as separate string in array
   - Format: "FirstName LastName" or "F. LastName"
   - Clean, no extra punctuation
   - Example: ["John Smith", "M. Johnson", "Sarah Williams"]

3. **DOI**: Standard DOI format for resolution APIs
   - Must start with "10." if present
   - Clean format without URL prefixes
   - Example: "10.1234/journal.2024.001"

4. **Journal**: Clean journal name for database queries
   - Full journal name preferred over abbreviations
   - Remove extra formatting, parentheses
   - Example: "Nature Medicine"

5. **Year**: Numeric format for date filtering
   - 4-digit NUMBER only (not string)
   - Example: 2024

6. **Volume**: Clean number for bibliographic APIs
   - Numbers only, no "Vol." prefix
   - Example: "15"

7. **Issue**: Clean number format
   - Numbers only, no "No." or "Issue" prefix
   - Example: "3"

8. **Pages**: Standard page range for citations
   - Format: "start-end" or single page
   - Example: "123-135" or "45"

9. **PMID**: PubMed ID for medical APIs
   - Numbers only, no "PMID:" prefix
   - Example: "12345678"

10. **PMCID**: PubMed Central ID for open access papers
    - Numbers only, no "PMC" prefix
    - Often appears near PMID in biomedical papers
    - Example: "9876543"

11. **Keywords**: API-compatible keyword list
    - Each keyword as separate string
    - Research-quality terms, no punctuation
    - Example: ["machine learning", "healthcare", "clinical outcomes"]

11. **Abstract**: Complete clean text (HIGHEST PRIORITY)
    - Remove formatting, line breaks, extra spaces
    - Complete sentences, proper punctuation
    - Search thoroughly across ALL pages
    - This is CRITICAL for Semantic Scholar and other APIs

12. **Publisher**: Clean organization name
    - Official publisher name
    - Example: "Elsevier" or "Nature Publishing Group"

ABSTRACT EXTRACTION PRIORITY:
- Look thoroughly across ALL pages for abstract sections
- Extract COMPLETE text, including multiple paragraphs
- Check: Abstract, Summary, Introduction summary paragraphs
- This field is CRITICAL for API enrichment success

Return JSON format:
{
  "Title": "clean title without formatting",
  "Authors": ["Author One", "Author Two"],
  "DOI": "10.xxxx/xxxxx",
  "Journal": "clean journal name", 
  "Year": 2024,
  "Volume": "15",
  "Issue": "3", 
  "Pages": "123-135",
  "Abstract": "complete clean abstract text",
  "Keywords": ["keyword1", "keyword2"],
  "PMID": "12345678",
  "PMCID": "9876543",
  "Publisher": "publisher name"
}

Return null for fields not clearly visible. The Abstract field is MOST IMPORTANT for downstream API success.

extracted_data.Title: Patient-Tailored Augmented Reality Games for Assessing Upper Extremity Motor Impairments in Parkinson’s Disease and Stroke
extracted_data.Abstract: In clinical practice, upper extremity motor impairments are commonly assessed with disease-specific, subjectively scored and low-resolution rating scales that often do not consider the variations in tasks and environment that are essential aspects of daily life. Augmented reality (AR) systems with contactless tracking of the hand and upper body offer opportunities for objective quantification of motor (dys)function in a challenging, engaging and patient-tailored environment. In this study, we explore the potential of AR for evaluating 1) speed and goal-directedness of movements within the individually determined interaction space, 2) adaptation of hand opening to objects of different sizes, and 3) obstacle avoidance in healthy individuals (N=10) and two highly prevalent neurological conditions (N=10 patients with Parkinson’s Disease and N=10 stroke patients). We successfully implemented three AR games to evaluate these key aspects of motor function. As expected, PD patients moved slower than controls and needed more time for task completion. No differences were observed between stroke patients and controls, perhaps because motor impairments in this patient group were relatively mild. Importantly, usability of our AR system was good and considerably improved compared to our previous study due to more natural and patient-tailored interaction. Although this study highlights the potential of AR for assessing motor impairments in patients with neurological conditions and provide starting points for further improvement, there are still many steps to be taken towards application in clinical practice.

We successfully implemented three AR games to evaluate these key aspects of motor function. As expected, PD patients moved slower than controls and needed more time for task completion. No differences were observed between stroke patients and controls, perhaps because motor impairments in this patient group were relatively mild. AbstractText: In clinical practice, upper extremity motor impairments are commonly assessed with disease-specific, subjectively scored and low-resolution rating scales that often do not consider the variations in tasks and environment that are essential aspects of daily life. Augmented reality (AR) systems with contactless tracking of the hand and upper body offer opportunities for objective quantification of motor (dys)function in a challenging, engaging and patient-tailored environment. In this study, we explore the potential of AR for evaluating 1) speed and goal-directedness of movements within the individually determined interaction space, 2) adaptation of hand opening to objects of different sizes, and 3) obstacle avoidance in healthy individuals (N = 10) and two highly prevalent neurological conditions (N = 10 patients with Parkinson's Disease and N = 10 stroke patients). We successfully implemented three AR games to evaluate these key aspects of motor function. As expected, PD patients moved slower than controls and needed more time for task completion. No differences were observed between stroke patients and controls, perhaps because motor impairments in this patient group were relatively mild. Importantly, usability of our AR system was good and considerably improved compared to our previous study due to more natural and patient-tailored interaction. Although our findings testify to the potential of AR for assessing motor impairments in patients with neurological conditions and provide starting points for further improvement, there are still many steps to be taken towards application in clinical practice.

data.abstractText: In clinical practice, upper extremity motor impairments are commonly assessed with disease-specific, subjectively scored and low-resolution rating scales that often do not consider the variations in tasks and environment that are essential aspects of daily life. Augmented reality (AR) systems with contactless tracking of the hand and upper body offer opportunities for objective quantification of motor (dys)function in a challenging, engaging and patient-tailored environment. In this study, we explore the potential of AR for evaluating 1) speed and goal-directedness of movements within the individually determined interaction space, 2) adaptation of hand opening to objects of different sizes, and 3) obstacle avoidance in healthy individuals (N = 10) and two highly prevalent neurological conditions (N = 10 patients with Parkinson's Disease and N = 10 stroke patients). We successfully implemented three AR games to evaluate these key aspects of motor function. As expected, PD patients moved slower than controls and needed more time for task completion. No differences were observed between stroke patients and controls, perhaps because motor impairments in this patient group were relatively mild. Importantly, usability of our AR system was good and considerably improved compared to our previous study due to more natural and patient-tailored interaction. Although our findings testify to the potential of AR for assessing motor impairments in patients with neurological conditions and provide starting points for further improvement, there are still many steps to be taken towards application in clinical practice.

data.title: Patient-Tailored Augmented Reality Games for Assessing Upper Extremity Motor Impairments in Parkinson’s Disease and Stroke
data.abstract: In clinical practice, upper extremity motor impairments are commonly assessed with disease-specific, subjectively scored and low-resolution rating scales that often do not consider the variations in tasks and environment that are essential aspects of daily life. Augmented reality (AR) systems with contactless tracking of the hand and upper body offer opportunities for objective quantification of motor (dys)function in a challenging, engaging and patient-tailored environment. In this study, we explore the potential of AR for evaluating 1) speed and goal-directedness of movements within the individually determined interaction space, 2) adaptation of hand opening to objects of different sizes, and 3) obstacle avoidance in healthy individuals (N = 10) and two highly prevalent neurological conditions (N = 10 patients with Parkinson’s Disease and N = 10 stroke patients). We successfully implemented three AR games to evaluate these key aspects of motor function. As expected, PD patients moved slower than controls and needed more time for task completion. No differences were observed between stroke patients and controls, perhaps because motor impairments in this patient group were relatively mild. Importantly, usability of our AR system was good and considerably improved compared to our previous study due to more natural and patient-tailored interaction. Although our findings testify to the potential of AR for assessing motor impairments in patients with neurological conditions and provide starting points for further improvement, there are still many steps to be taken towards application in clinical practice.

consensus_result.Title: Patient-Tailored Augmented Reality Games for Assessing Upper Extremity Motor Impairments in Parkinson’s Disease and Stroke
consensus_result.Abstract: In clinical practice, upper extremity motor impairments are commonly assessed with disease-specific, subjectively scored and low-resolution rating scales that often do not consider the variations in tasks and environment that are essential aspects of daily life. Augmented reality (AR) systems with contactless tracking of the hand and upper body offer opportunities for objective quantification of motor (dys)function in a challenging, engaging and patient-tailored environment. In this study, we explore the potential of AR for evaluating 1) speed and goal-directedness of movements within the individually determined interaction space, 2) adaptation of hand opening to objects of different sizes, and 3) obstacle avoidance in healthy individuals (N=10) and two highly prevalent neurological conditions (N=10 patients with Parkinson's Disease and N=10 stroke patients). We successfully implemented three AR games to evaluate these key aspects of motor function. As expected, PD patients moved slower than controls and needed more time for task completion. No differences were observed between stroke patients and controls, perhaps because motor impairments in this patient group were relatively mild. Importantly, usability of our AR system was good and considerably improved compared to our previous study due to more natural and patient-tailored interaction. Although this study highlights the potential of AR for assessing motor impairments in patients with neurological conditions and provide starting points for further improvement, there are still many steps to be taken towards application in clinical practice.

confidence_factors.reasoning: Vision data used as foundation with significant enhancements from multiple coherent API sources. Issue number corrected from vision (11) to API consensus (12). Added PMCID, PMID, citation count, and open access status from validated sources. Keywords enriched from MeSH terms in Europe PMC.

api_success_summary.insights: Strong coherence among major APIs (Crossref, Europe PMC, Semantic Scholar, OpenAlex, Unpaywall, PubMed). Europe PMC provided the most comprehensive enhancements including MeSH terms and affiliations. DOAJ failed due to missing DOI search, while arXiv and DataCite had no matches.

llm_topics_json.prompt_sent:
You are a scientific research assistant extracting data for academic comparison tables with statistical rigor.

CRITICAL INSTRUCTIONS FOR ACADEMIC COMPARISON:

- SYSTEMATICALLY scan ALL content: text, tables, figures, charts, appendices
- PRIORITIZE quantitative data while preserving qualitative context
- When conflicts exist in the paper, prioritize MOST RECENT/AUTHORITATIVE source
- Extract ALL relevant details mentioned - DON'T truncate important information
- Include statistical tests results (Z-scores, t-values, chi-square, etc.)
- Extract accuracy rates, completion rates, success rates with specific numbers
- Capture comparative data (e.g., "46% vs 27%", "Group A: 64.5%, Group B: 68.2%")
- Use proper numeric format: "p = 0.007" not "p = .007", "81" not "eighty-one"

COMPREHENSIVE CAPTURE REQUIREMENTS:

- List ALL hardware components: cameras, sensors, headsets, controllers, phones, tablets, webcams, probes
- Include ALL software details: platforms, SDKs, libraries, export formats (CSV, JSON), feedback systems
- Capture ALL measurement instruments: scales, questionnaires, assessment tools (SUS, NASA-TLX, FES-I, MoCA, IKDC, VAS, ABC scale, WHODAS 2.0, etc.)
- Note ALL technical specifications: resolutions, frame rates, tracking capabilities, joint counts
- Include ALL study phases: pilot tests, technical validation, user studies, expert evaluations
- Capture ALL procedural details: training time, calibration steps, data export processes, real-time feedback

CONFLICT RESOLUTION:

- If conflicting information exists, prioritize methods/results over abstract
- When uncertain, include both: "X in abstract, Y in methods section"

Extract the following 7 scientific topics:

1. *study_design*: Extract the PRIMARY study type/design using the most specific and authoritative terminology from the paper's methods section. Recognize equivalent terms: "RCT" = "Randomized controlled trial", "Pilot study" = "Feasibility pilot study", "Cross-sectional" = "Observational cross-sectional", "User study" = "User evaluation study". When multiple study type descriptions exist, prioritize the most comprehensive version from methods over abstract. Include specific qualifiers when mentioned (e.g., "multicenter", "double-blind", "waitlist-controlled") as these add valuable detail. Format as brief phrase describing core study methodology, avoiding generic terms like "study" or "research" alone.

2. *methodology*: ONE comprehensive sentence covering: technology + application + key technical details. Include: ALL device models, software platforms, measurement tools, statistical analyses. Capture ALL hardware components mentioned (cameras, sensors, controllers, probes, etc.). Include ALL software features (real-time feedback, data export, tracking capabilities). Mention ALL technical specifications (joint tracking numbers, frame rates, resolutions). Example: "Microsoft HoloLens 2 with HoloAnatomy platform for 3D anatomical procedural visualization using real-time motion tracking of 25 joints with CSV data export and real-time visual feedback".

3. *sample_size*: Format: "X participants/patients" (use paper's exact terminology). Include TOTAL numbers if multiple groups exist. Include ALL test phases: technical tests, pilot studies, user evaluations. Example: "25 total: 23 biomedical students + 2 clinical experts; 50 technical validation readings".

4. *population*: ALL demographic details and characteristics not captured in sample_size. Include age, profession, condition, experience, setting details. Add specific numbers when available. Include recruitment sources and inclusion/exclusion criteria.

5. *primary_outcome*: Include ALL measurement tools, scales, timing, specific metrics, usability criteria (ease of use, realism, anatomical accuracy). List ALL assessment instruments used and functional scales (SUS, NASA-TLX, FES-I, MoCA, IKDC, VAS, ABC scale, WHODAS 2.0, etc.), and evaluation dimensions beyond the primary measures.. Include ALL comparison conditions and timepoints. Example: "Patient understanding via 5-point Likert scale assessed pre/post intervention, plus SUS usability scores and NASA-TLX workload assessment".

6. *key_findings*: PRIORITIZE statistical results with practical implications. Format: "Finding 1: [statistical data + meaning]. Finding 2: [data + context]". Include ALL significant findings, p-values, effect sizes, accuracy rates, comparative data, accuracy measurements (sub-mm, degrees), specific understanding domains (surgical risks, operative steps, recovery), and detailed performance metrics beyond statistical significance. Present ALL questionnaire results, prototype performance, qualitative benefits. Include ALL cost factors, training requirements, implementation details. Capture ALL comparison groups and their specific results. Be comprehensive - capture complete findings picture. Include ALL technical specifications mentioned: accuracy measurements (sub-mm, degrees).

7. *limitations*: Extract ALL limitations from limitation/discussion sections. Include sample size issues, technical equipment requirements, methodological, practical constraints. Mention ALL equipment needs, calibration requirements, manufacturing variability. Include ALL generalizability issues, validity concerns, implementation barriers. Capture training requirements, cost constraints, specialized equipment needs. Note real-world applicability issues and clinical implementation challenges. Don't summarize - capture complete limitation landscape.

Return as valid JSON with this EXACT structure:

{
  "study_design": "string",
  "methodology": "string",
  "sample_size": "string",
  "population": "string",
  "primary_outcome": "string",
  "key_findings": "string",
  "limitations": "string"
}

extracted_topics.population: PD patients (mean age 60.8, disease duration 11.9 years), stroke patients (>12 weeks post-stroke, mean age 60.5), healthy controls (mean age 61.6); recruited from outpatient clinics; able to lift arms above shoulder level.
extracted_topics.limitations: Small sample size; limited field of view in HMD; potential ceiling effects in MRD; need for larger studies to improve sensitivity; requirement for patients to lift arms above shoulder level may exclude some stroke patients.
extracted_topics.methodology: AIRO II head-mounted display with Leap Motion for contactless tracking and Logitech C922 Pro Stream Webcam for marker recognition; Microsoft Kinect v2 sensor for body tracking; Unity3D for software integration; data processed using MATLAB; real-time visual feedback and CSV data export.
extracted_topics.sample_size: 30 participants: 10 PD patients, 10 stroke patients, 10 healthy controls
extracted_topics.key_findings: Finding 1: PD patients showed reduced maximum reach distance (F(3,51) = 4.6, p = 0.007, η² = 0.21). Finding 2: Melody Cubes task showed significant differences in hand opening (F(2,36) = 22.8, p < 0.001, η² = 0.56). Finding 3: Hungry Squirrel task success rate was lower in scenario VO (100 [94–100%], p = 0.01).
extracted_topics.primary_outcome: Motor function assessed via maximum reach distance, success rate, movement speed, and relative path length; usability evaluated using SUS and NASA-TLX; engagement assessed with GEQ.
